description: From Middle English pleit, from Anglo-Norman pleit (compare Old French ploit), from Latin plectō, which is akin to Old Norse flétta (Danish flette) and to Russian сплетать (spletatʹ). Doublet of plight (“plait, fold”).

entries.meaning: A flat fold; a doubling, as of cloth; a pleat.
A braid, as of hair or straw; a plat.

verbs.description: plait (third-person singular simple present plaits, present participle plaiting, simple past and past participle plaited)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fold; to double in narrow folds; to pleat
(transitive) To interweave the strands or locks of; to braid
